meta.content: Laser diodes employing a strain-compensated GaAs1−xBix/GaAs1−yPy single quantum well (SQW) active region were grown by organometallic vapor phase epitaxy (OMVPE). High resolution x-ray diffraction, room temperature photoluminescence, and real-time optical reflectance measurements during the OMVPE growth were used to find the optimum process window for the growth of the active region material. Systematic post-growth in situ thermal anneals of various lengths were carried out in order to investigate the impacts of thermal annealing on the laser device performance characteristics. While the lowest threshold current density was achieved after the thermal annealing for 30 min at 630 °C, a gradual decrease in the external differential quantum efficiency was observed as the annealing time increases. It was observed that the temperature sensitivities of the threshold current density increase while those of lasing wavelength and slope efficiency remain nearly constant with increasing annealing time. Z-contrast scanning transmission electron microscopic) analysis revealed inhomogeneous Bi distribution within the QW active region.

div.div:
Laser diodes employing a strain-compensated GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
/GaAs
1−y
P
y
single quantum well (SQW) active region were grown by organometallic vapor phase epitaxy (OMVPE). High resolution x-ray diffraction, room temperature photoluminescence, and real-time optical reflectance measurements during the OMVPE growth were used to find the optimum process window for the growth of the active region material. Systematic post-growth
in situ
thermal anneals of various lengths were carried out in order to investigate the impacts of thermal annealing on the laser device performance characteristics. While the lowest threshold current density was achieved after the thermal annealing for 30 min at 630 °C, a gradual decrease in the external differential quantum efficiency was observed as the annealing time increases. It was observed that the temperature sensitivities of the threshold current density increase while those of lasing wavelength and slope efficiency remain nearly constant with increasing annealing time. Z-contrast scanning transmission electron microscopic) analysis revealed inhomogeneous Bi distribution within the QW active region.
INTRODUCTION
Section:

The GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
alloy system has attracted much attention as a promising narrow band gap material for applications to microelectronic and optoelectronic devices.
1–4
1. F. Dimroth, “
High‐efficiency solar cells from III‐V compound semiconductors
,” Phys. Status Solidi C
3
(3), 373–
379
(2006).
https://doi.org/10.1002/pssc.200564172
2. P. Ludewig, N. Knaub, N. Hossain, S. Reinhard, L. Nattermann, I. P. Marko, S. R. Jin, K. Hild, S. Chatterjee, W. Stolz, and S. J. Sweeney, “
Electrical injection Ga (AsBi)/(AlGa) As single quantum well laser
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
102
(24), 242115 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4811736
3. Z. D. Marks, I. W. Haygood, and B. Van Zeghbroeck, “
Analysis of the GaAs/GaAsBi material system for heterojunction bipolar transistors
,” IEEE Trans. Electron Devices
60
(1), 200–
205
(2013).
https://doi.org/10.1109/TED.2012.2226592
4. B. Fluegel, S. Francoeur, A. Mascarenhas, S. Tixier, E. C. Young, and T. Tiedje, “
Giant spin-orbit bowing in GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
,” Phys. Rev. Lett.
97
(6), 067205 (2006).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevLett.97.067205
Prior theoretical and experimental reports have shown a rapid reduction in the band gap(E
g
) (62–84 meV/%Bi) and an increase in spin-orbit splitting (Δ
so
) with increasing Bi incorporation within the GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
alloy system.
5–8
5. C. A. Broderick, M. Usman, and E. P. O'Reilly, “
Derivation of 12-and 14-band k· p Hamiltonians for dilute bismide and bismide-nitride semiconductors
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
28
(12), 125025 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0268-1242/28/12/125025
6. S. Francoeur, M. J. Seong, A. Mascarenhas, S. Tixier, M. Adamcyk, and T. Tiedje, “
Band gap of GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
, 0 < x < 3.6%
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
82
(22), 3874–
3876
(2003).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1581983
7. K. Oe and H. Okamoto, “
New semiconductor alloy GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
grown by metal organic vapor phase epitaxy
,” Jpn. J. Appl. Phys., Part 2
37
(11A), L1283 (1998).
https://doi.org/10.1143/JJAP.37.L1283
8. D. Madouri, A. Boukra, A. Zaoui, and M. Ferhat, “
Bismuth alloying in GaAs: A first-principles study
,” Comput. Mater. Sci.
43
(4), 818–
822
(2008).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.commatsci.2008.01.059
This rapid reduction in E
g
allows the GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
quantum well (QW) active regions to be a suitable candidate as a novel active region in lasers emitting in the telecom wavelength region (λ ∼ 1.3–1.55
μ
m).
2
2. P. Ludewig, N. Knaub, N. Hossain, S. Reinhard, L. Nattermann, I. P. Marko, S. R. Jin, K. Hild, S. Chatterjee, W. Stolz, and S. J. Sweeney, “
Electrical injection Ga (AsBi)/(AlGa) As single quantum well laser
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
102
(24), 242115 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4811736
QW active regions emitting in this wavelength region are also attractive for implementation in GaAs-based Vertical Cavity Surface Emitting Lasers (VCSELs), allowing the use of high index-contrast AlGaAs/GaAs Distributed Bragg Reflector (DBR) mirrors to form the laser microcavity. This rapid band gap narrowing resulting from the introduction of Bi into GaAs has been attributed to the interaction between the localized Bi resonant level and the valence band of GaAs within a valence band anti-crossing model (VBAC), which results in a large valence band offset (VBO), ∼55 meV/%Bi, and a relatively small conduction band offset (CBO), ∼15 meV/%Bi, at GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
/GaAs heterojunctions, particularly within the dilute Bi regime.
9
9. M. Usman, C. A. Broderick, Z. Batool, K. Hild, T. J. Hosea, S. J. Sweeney, and E. P. O'Reilly, “
Impact of alloy disorder on the band structure of compressively strained GaBi
x
As
1−x
,” Phys. Rev. B
87
(11), 115104 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1103/PhysRevB.87.115104
Therefore, it is important to choose a higher band gap material as an electron barrier for the applications where tight confinement of both electrons and holes is important. While the first successful operation of an electrically injected GaAs
0.978
Bi
0.022
single quantum well (SQW) laser employed Al
0.2
Ga
0.8
As barriers,
2
2. P. Ludewig, N. Knaub, N. Hossain, S. Reinhard, L. Nattermann, I. P. Marko, S. R. Jin, K. Hild, S. Chatterjee, W. Stolz, and S. J. Sweeney, “
Electrical injection Ga (AsBi)/(AlGa) As single quantum well laser
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
102
(24), 242115 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4811736
we recently reported the effectiveness of tensile-strained GaAs
1−y
P
y
as a QW barrier within a GaAs
0.975
Bi
0.025
/GaAs
0.8
P
0.2
heterostructure for both the strain-balancing and tight electron confinement.
10
10. H. Kim, Y. Guan, K. Forghani, T. F. Kuech, and L. J. Mawst, “
Laser diodes employing GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
/GaAs
1−y
P
y
quantum well active regions
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
32
(7), 075007 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1361-6641/aa729b
Improved threshold current density and a longer lasing wavelength from the GaAs
0.975
Bi
0.025
/GaAs
0.8
P
0.2
active region laser, compared to the GaAs
0.975
Bi
0.025
/GaAs active region laser, were observed as a result of the enhanced carrier confinement within the active region.
10
10. H. Kim, Y. Guan, K. Forghani, T. F. Kuech, and L. J. Mawst, “
Laser diodes employing GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
/GaAs
1−y
P
y
quantum well active regions
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
32
(7), 075007 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1361-6641/aa729b
Also, the strain-balancing is particularly crucial for structures employing a multiple quantum well (MQW) and/or high Bi concentrations to prevent strain relaxation.

The metastable GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
alloy exhibits a large miscibility gap, which requires its growth to be carried out with non-typical growth parameters, involving a low growth temperature (T
growth
∼ 400 °C) and near-stoichiometric V/III flux ratio for molecular beam epitaxy (MBE) and near-unity V/III gas-phase ratio for OMVPE in order to incorporate Bi into the host GaAs matrix.
10,12–14
10. H. Kim, Y. Guan, K. Forghani, T. F. Kuech, and L. J. Mawst, “
Laser diodes employing GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
/GaAs
1−y
P
y
quantum well active regions
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
32
(7), 075007 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1361-6641/aa729b
12. T. F. Kuech, S. E. Babcock, and L. Mawst, “
Growth far from equilibrium: Examples from III-V semiconductors
,” Appl. Phys. Rev.
3
(4), 040801 (2016).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4944801
13. K. Forghani, Y. Guan, A. Wood, S. Babock, L. Mawst, and T. F. Kuech, “
The effect of the Bi precursors,(CH3) 3Bi and (C2H5) 3Bi, on the metal‐organic vapor phase epitaxy of GaAs
1−y
Bi
y
films
,” Chem. Vap. Deposition
21
(7-8-9), 166–
175
(2015).
https://doi.org/10.1002/cvde.201507160
14. S. Tixier, M. Adamcyk, T. Tiedje, S. Francoeur, A. Mascarenhas, P. Wei, and F. Schiettekatte, “
Molecular beam epitaxy growth of GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
82
(14), 2245–
2247
(2003).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.1565499
Materials grown under these conditions can exhibit a high concentration of point defects and its associated defect complexes, which can act as non-radiative recombination centers.
15
15. M. Kaminska, E. R. Weber, Z. Liliental‐Weber, R. Leon, and Z. U. Rek, “
Stoichiometry‐related defects in GaAs grown by molecular‐beam epitaxy at low temperatures
,” J. Vac. Sci. Technol., B: Microelectron. Process. Phenom.
7
(4), 710–
713
(1989).
https://doi.org/10.1116/1.584630
Furthermore, especially for the OMVPE growth, significant carbon contamination results from employing such a low growth temperature, as the hydrocarbon radicals from the metal-organic precursors are not completely removed from the growth front.
13
13. K. Forghani, Y. Guan, A. Wood, S. Babock, L. Mawst, and T. F. Kuech, “
The effect of the Bi precursors,(CH3) 3Bi and (C2H5) 3Bi, on the metal‐organic vapor phase epitaxy of GaAs
1−y
Bi
y
films
,” Chem. Vap. Deposition
21
(7-8-9), 166–
175
(2015).
https://doi.org/10.1002/cvde.201507160
It has been reported that incorporated carbon reduces the minority carrier lifetime of dilute-nitride III/V alloys, limiting the performance of, for example, single junction solar cells.
16
16. T. W. Kim, K. Kim, J. J. Lee, T. F. Kuech, L. J. Mawst, N. P. Wells, S. D. LaLumondiere, Y. Sin, W. T. Lotshaw, and S. C. Moss, “
Impact of thermal annealing on bulk InGaAsSbN materials grown by metalorganic vapor phase epitaxy
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
104
(5), 051915 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4864111
Therefore, both the point defects and a high degree of carbon contamination could lead to a significant degradation in the radiative efficiency of the materials. For efficient light emission, the growth parameters must therefore be carefully optimized for the OMVPE growth of device quality GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
films.

Prior reports have shown that the luminescent properties of GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
can be further improved by post-growth thermal annealing at the temperatures ranging from 500 to 800 °C.
17–22
17. H. Kim, K. Forghani, Y. Guan, K. Kim, A. W. Wood, J. Lee, S. E. Babcock, T. F. Kuech, and L. J. Mawst, “
Impact of
in-situ
annealing on dilute-bismide materials and its application to photovoltaics
,” J. Cryst. Growth
452
, 276–
280
(2016).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcrysgro.2016.04.039
18. H. Kim, K. Forghani, Y. Guan, G. Luo, A. Anand, D. Morgan, T. F. Kuech, L. J. Mawst, Z. R. Lingley, B. J. Foran, and Y. Sin, “
Strain-compensated GaAs
1−y
P
y
/GaAs
1−z
Bi
z
/GaAs
1−y
P
y
quantum wells for laser applications
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
30
(9), 094011 (2015).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0268-1242/30/9/094011
19. A. R. Mohmad, F. Bastiman, C. J. Hunter, R. Richards, S. J. Sweeney, J. S. Ng, and J. P. R. David, “
Effects of rapid thermal annealing on GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
alloys
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
101
(1), 012106 (2012).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4731784
20. P. C. Grant, D. Fan, A. Mosleh, S. Q. Yu, V. G. Dorogan, M. E. Hawkridge, Y. I. Mazur, M. Benamara, G. J. Salamo, and S. R. Johnson, “
Rapid thermal annealing effect on GaAsBi/GaAs single quantum wells grown by molecular beam epitaxy
,” J. Vac. Sci. Technol., B: Nanotechnol. Microelectron.: Mater., Process., Meas., Phenom.
32
(2), 02C119 (2014).
https://doi.org/10.1116/1.4868110
21. S. Mazzucato, P. Boonpeng, H. Carrère, D. Lagarde, A. Arnoult, G. Lacoste, T. Zhang, A. Balocchi, T. Amand, X. Marie, and C. Fontaine, “
Reduction of defect density by rapid thermal annealing in GaAsBi studied by time-resolved photoluminescence
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
28
(2), 022001 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0268-1242/28/2/022001
22. Z. Chine, H. Fitouri, I. Zaied, A. Rebey, and B. El Jani, “
Photoreflectance and photoluminescence study of annealing effects on GaAsBi layers grown by metalorganic vapor phase epitaxy
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
25
(6), 065009 (2010).
https://doi.org/10.1088/0268-1242/25/6/065009
These studies mainly focused on increase in the photoluminescence intensity observed after thermal annealing by either rapid thermal annealing(RTA) or
in situ
annealing within the OMVPE reactor. While our prior study demonstrated a reduced threshold current density from the annealed SQW GaAs
0.975
Bi
0.025
/GaAs
0.8
P
0.2
laser diode,
10
10. H. Kim, Y. Guan, K. Forghani, T. F. Kuech, and L. J. Mawst, “
Laser diodes employing GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
/GaAs
1−y
P
y
quantum well active regions
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
32
(7), 075007 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1361-6641/aa729b
it lacked a thorough investigation on the effects of post-growth thermal annealing conditions on the relevant device parameters such as the threshold current density, slope efficiency, and the characteristic temperature coefficients, T
0
and T
1
. Here, we report a more comprehensive analysis of the impact of the post-growth thermal annealing on these device parameters.
EXPERIMENTAL DETAIL
Section:

The materials were grown in a close-coupled-showerhead vertical OMVPE reactor with a rotating susceptor. The growth was monitored in real time by the commercial optical reflectance system (EpiTT™, Laytec). The GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
was grown by the simultaneous feed of triethyl gallium(TEGa), trimethyl bismuth(TMBi), and tertiarybutyl arsine(TBAs) at 430 °C, while the GaAs interlayers and GaAs
1−y
P
y
barriers were grown using trimethyl gallium(TMGa), arsine(AsH
3
), and phosphine (PH
3
) at 630 °C after the GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
growth was paused. This growth interruption and temperature ramping are believed to desorb segregated Bi, which remains on the surface of bismide-containing film.
2,10,17
2. P. Ludewig, N. Knaub, N. Hossain, S. Reinhard, L. Nattermann, I. P. Marko, S. R. Jin, K. Hild, S. Chatterjee, W. Stolz, and S. J. Sweeney, “
Electrical injection Ga (AsBi)/(AlGa) As single quantum well laser
,” Appl. Phys. Lett.
102
(24), 242115 (2013).
https://doi.org/10.1063/1.4811736
10. H. Kim, Y. Guan, K. Forghani, T. F. Kuech, and L. J. Mawst, “
Laser diodes employing GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
/GaAs
1−y
P
y
quantum well active regions
,” Semicond. Sci. Technol.
32
(7), 075007 (2017).
https://doi.org/10.1088/1361-6641/aa729b
17. H. Kim, K. Forghani, Y. Guan, K. Kim, A. W. Wood, J. Lee, S. E. Babcock, T. F. Kuech, and L. J. Mawst, “
Impact of
in-situ
annealing on dilute-bismide materials and its application to photovoltaics
,” J. Cryst. Growth
452
, 276–
280
(2016).
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.jcrysgro.2016.04.039
The material growth parameters were optimized by growing 5-period multiple quantum well (MQW) structures on nominally exact (100) semi-insulating GaAs substrates (within ±0.1°). The average Bi concentration and thickness of each QW were extracted by high resolution x-ray diffraction (HR-XRD) ω-2θ scans around the GaAs (004) reflections and fitting to the dynamic simulation from this 5-period MQW structure. In order to evaluate the luminescent properties, photoluminescence (PL) measurements at room temperature were carried out by using a frequency-doubled Nd:YAG (532 nm) excitation source, 300 g/mm grating monochromator, and liquid nitrogen cooled InGaAs detectors. After finding an optimized growth condition, the laser diode structures employing a SQW were grown on a nominally exact n
+
GaAs substrate. For the growth of GaAs
0.75
P
0.25
, TMGa, AsH
3
, and PH
3
were used as precursors. Trimethyl-aluminum (TMAl), TMGa, and AsH
3
were used for the (Al)GaAs growth within the laser structures. Disilane (Si
2
H
6
) was used as a n-type doping source while carbon tetrabromide (CBr
4
) was used for p-type doping in the Al
0.6
Ga
0.4
As upper cladding layer, and diethyl-zinc (DEZn) was used for heavily doped p
+
GaAs contact layer. After the laser structure growth, the wafers were cleaved and one section of each sample was subjected to an additional
in situ
annealing within the OMVPE reactor at a fixed temperature of 630 °C under AsH
3
(3.8 mmol/min) for 30, 60, 90, and 120 min. 27
μ
m-wide ridge waveguide lasers were fabricated by a standard photolithographic process from both the as-grown and annealed samples. The wet etching using H
3
PO
4
:H
2
O
2
:H
2
O = 3:1:25 was carried out to form the etched ridge waveguide structure, using a patterned photoresist mask. 200 nm-thick SiN
x
was deposited by plasma-enhanced chemical vapor deposition for the electrical passivation. The wafer was subsequently thinned to 150
μ
m. Contact layers consisting of Ti/Pt/Au (25/50/300 nm) were e-beam evaporated on the top surface to form the ohmic contact to p+ GaAs. Contact to the n-type region was made to the backside of the wafer using a AuGe/Ni/Au (100/35/200 nm) contact metallurgy. The contact metals were alloyed at 375 °C for 30 s using RTA. Devices were measured
as-cleaved
(i.e., no facet coatings) at room temperature under pulsed current operation with a cavity length of 0.2 cm. The electroluminescence (EL) data were collected using a grating spectrometer and Si photodetector, while the output power from one facet was measured using calibrated InGaAs photodiode. In addition, the temperature dependency of the threshold current density, an increase in the output power vs. increase in the injection current, and the lasing photon energy were measured within the temperature range from 283 to 323 K. The high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF), or “z-contrast,” imaging method in an aberration corrected scanning transmission electron microscope (STEM) was used to investigate the homogeneity of the Bi and interfacial abruptness within an annealed laser structure. The STEM specimen was prepared by a focused ion beam (FIB) lift-out technique. Final thinning was performed with Ga
+
ions at 2 kV to minimize the surface damage often associated with FIB sample preparation.
RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
Section:

In our prior study, we utilized
in situ
optical reflectance measurements to determine the growth rate reduction during the GaAs

FIG. 6.
Summary of the change in the characteristic temperatures, T
0
(black square) and T
1
(red circle), and the temperature coefficient (blue triangle) of the lasing wavelength as a function of annealing time, measured from 283 K to 323 K. The fitting equations are shown at the upper right corner. The solid lines are for guiding eyes.
CONCLUSION
Section:

We have performed a systematic investigation on the impacts of the post-growth
in situ
thermal annealing on GaAs
0.965
Bi
0.035
SQW lasers grown by OMVPE. To optimize the GaAs
1−x
Bi
x
material growth for the device application,
in situ
optical reflectance, HR-XRD, and RT-PL measurements were employed to find the narrow window of growth parameters resulting in good structural and luminescence properties. A gradual decrease in the laser slope efficiency was observed as the annealing time increased, while the maximum PL intensity as well as the lowest threshold current density were obtained after the annealing for 30 min at 630 °C. STEM analysis indicates inhomogeneous Bi distribution within the SQW that is most likely due to the high TMBi/V gas phase ratio used in this work. This inhomogeneity resulted in the graded Bi profile, which might have led to the increased carrier leakage under excessive band filling conditions. The strong temperature sensitivity of the slope efficiency also implies a high degree of the quantum well carrier leakage. These observations indicate that a uniform Bi profile within the QW and the suppression of carrier leakage by employing higher bandgap materials (i.e., higher P-content GaAsP) are the critical factors for improving the dilute bismide-based device performance. While the external device parameters such as the change in the threshold current densities, slope efficiencies, and temperature sensitivities were investigated, additional studies are needed to extract internal device parameters including the material gain parameter and internal loss, by employing a multi-segment contact method.

9
(5), 1275–

(2003).
